div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1905..

It is understood that tho German answer to the French note will be presented in a few days, but Prince Radolin, will discuss its pur- port with M. Rouvier before its arrival. The impression now prevails in France that there is no ground for apprehension, and that a pacific solution is possible. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE CASE OF THE "ST KILDA"
OUTCOME OF NEGOTIATIONS

div.p: it outcome of the British representatirna arding the making of the St. Kilda" is at British war hipe will be sent to convey
iers to the Dnieper" and "Rion" to seateriering with shipping, sed to returu home nbediately
Ibe "Dnieper has arrived here with the view of the "St. Kilda on board. (Brutto
The Roman cruiser "Bayan" has been suo Besfully refioated.
(Reuter.)
The Khedive has left om his homeward voyage ; the Earl of Cromer, Sir James Reunell Rodd, Sir E. H. Vincent Corbett, and General Slade bade him farewell at the station. (/f.)
The Khedive has arrived.
(Hlavas.)
The Kledive bay arrived here (Reuter.)

The Earl and Countess of Londesborough entertained his Highness the Khedive at dinner on the 16th inst, at their residence, 5, South Audley-street. Later in the evening a concert was given, and Lord and Lady Londesborough were honored by the presence of their Royal Highnesses the Crown Prince and Crown Princess of Swedeu and Norway, their Royal Highnesses Prince Engève and Prince William of Sweden and Norway, and her Royal Highness Princes Frederica of Hanover. The London Symphony Orchestra took part in the programme.

div.head: NEW HELLENIC CABINET. FORMED BY M. RALLI.

div.p: M. Ralli has formed the Cabinet. (Harar. It
M. Ralli has formed a Cabinet. The Delyan nists declined to participate in it. (Peter

div.head:
BRITISH CRUISER COLLIDES
WITH GERMAN SHIP,
div.p: HM's oruiser "Carnarvon," bound for Gibraltar, collided with the German liner "Coblenz." The "Carnarvon" has taken her passengers on board, and towed the Coblenz" here in a leaking condition.
(Reuter)

div.head: RACING
div.p: Hardwicke Stakes: 1, Bachelor's Batton; 2, Queen of the Earth , 3, Flower Seller. (R.)

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: Surrey beat Derbyshire by 235 runs Essex beat Australians by 19 runs. Sussex beat Cambridge University by 65 runs. The match between Lancashire and Worcestershire has been drawn. (HmUtr)

div.head: HOME GOING TROOPS.
div.p: The American SS "Garonne," which came out 1 the Canal at day light to-day, had on bard 615 Runbit soldiers going burne parole. Amongst them were many badly wounded, and I was told that several deaths bed Occurred on the voyage. She sails for 1) desse this evening

div.head: DOG POISONING
div.p: The police, I hear, have witbuat previons mutice or permission, sent down there to Kil. 54 and poisoned all the dogs on the station, irrespective of ownership or wbether the dogs were "pariah." The action has caused some dissatisfaction

div.head: THEFTS OF TELEGRAPH WIRE
div.p: Several times of late most daring thefts of telegraph wire bave been committed on the Canal Company's linen close to the office. Friday night again saw a complete break in communication between here and all canal stations, and an investigation being made it I was found that whole lengths of wire had been
stolen from the post within a stone's throw of the office.

div.head: TUG OF WAR.
div.p: The fourth "Married" , "Single" tag-ofwar amongst the residents here, was held yesterday--and for the fourth time the married men won, after a hard tagsle. The teams were the same as before.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: A POLICE STATION
div.p: is to be built at Zerabi.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.--
div.p: Pomping stations are to be constructed at Korimat and Klessi, E. Ghireh

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT, LIMITED. --
div.p: Baron de Kusel Bey, general manager of F this company, is leaving London this week for lo E.ypt.
'The Mes Tus Fire KING" came into colli sion within francar in Sisters-street yesterday afte i sa tiered somewbat in consequence

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS
div.p: Dogs fonnd in the Boulac district of Cairo during to worrow night and at daylight on Wednesday will be poisoned by the police,

div.head: SMALL POX
div.p: has broken out in Kashtamna vilhge, El Dort district, Assonan. Instruc tions have been issued by the moudirieh relative to the notification of cases and tbe limewashing and cleansing of houses where the disease has appeared.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL. --
div.p: 17 vessels passed through the Canal on the 22nd inst., 14 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Austrian. The receipts for the day were frs. 479,683.44, making the total trom the 1st inst, frs. 6,165,349.86.

div.head: UNION ARTISTIQUE FRANCAINE. -
div.p: At the meeting of members on Saturday, M J. Paul W38 ananimously elected president. His place as "commissaire de surveillance will be taken by M. A. Bartolotti.

div.head: THE MAHMAL THEFT -
div.p: A court martial asb tewati yerlerday under the presidency of Kainakain Gillan Bey for the trial of those officers of the Malmai escort who were in 1 charge of the Surra at the time of the robbery

div.head: HELLES SHOULS -
div.p: At 10.30 a.. yester day the annual distribution of prizes to the fourth class of the gymnasium and commercial department of the schools of the Greek com munity ut Alexandria took place. The cere mony was attended by his Beatitade Mgr. Photios, Greek Orthodox Patriarck, and his clerical staff, M. N. Seotides, Hellenic ConsulGeneral at Alexandria, M. Benachi, president of the Greek outukunty of Alexaudria, and many other well-known members of the Hellenic colony. An eloquent speech was delivered by M. George Palæologu, head master of the school. | The distribution lasted till noon. To-day the Summer holidays of these schools commence.

div.head: MESARS, WALKEE AND MEMAHACHI's
div.p: renovated stores in Old Bourse street were opened to the public at 6 pm on Satarday, and from that hour until closing time there was a continuous stream of visitors to the splendid establishment which the firm have arranged in the must nodera style. The new arranget ment of the premises is a great improvement on the vid, all the goods in the firm's various departments being now, visible at & glance. Almost everything from a needle to grannaphone may be bad from the firm, who are to be congratulated on their ap to date methods. Visitors were isvishly entertained on Saturday at a well stocked buflet.

div.head: WORKMEN ENTOMBED. --
div.p: - Yesterday morning the news reached the Menshieh caracol that two workmen who were engaged in palling down the old Wakts building in Prank-street had been buried alive by the collapse of the walls. Superintendent Lynn, of the Fire Briganda, with his men, immediately starter for the scene of the socident, and found that the men were alive, the roof leame having fallen in such a way as to shield them from the falling stones. Stimulants were passed in through a little opening in the wall and the rescue party set to work to remove the debris. Great care was necessary if & further tall which might bave had tatal consequences was to be avoided, but the men were finaliy brought out and were found to be saffering trom very slight injuries, which were treated at the bospital

div.head: THE CUSTAGION OF EXAMPLE
div.p: Shortly after midnight last Saturday & the boarded the Cairo Laxor express on the way to Maghaghs and got into a first-olasa carriage which was oecopied by Said Eifondi Saleh, of the Native Parquet, and his family. The thief's investigations into the contents of the luggage rack were qui kly put an end to Said Effendi was a wake, and the thief was seized and handed over to the station master at Maghagha. He cave the names of Osman and Mohamed It is obvious that this is a case of an access ful innitation. Aadrous Meloks, whose exploita have been recorded in the whole Egyptian Press, ** & train-robber sod Oaxsan alias Mobamed mast needs be one too. He will have plenty of spare time to brood over the results of what may be described as criminal plagiarism.

div.head: THE STATE RAILWAYS. FORMATION OF NEW BOARD.
div.p: We understand that Major Johnstone, whilst in England, selected a gentleman, thoroughly expeh rienced in railway matters, who will be appointedt as his special secretary. It is also said that a new-board will be created, consisting of Mus- | tapha Pasha Fehmy, Sir Vincent Corbett, Sir William Warstin, M. Barois, and Scandar Pasha Febmy. The daties of the new board will be to consider and approve of all schemes involving the expenditure of large sums of money, and they will only be called together to consider such questions. Beyond this, Major Johnstone and his colleagues will have entire responsibility in the management of the railways, and we understand that the former's position will more resemble that of general manager of an English railway than it has formerly done, as was suggested in the report of the Railway Commission which visited this country.

We pablish this information under all reserved and we have received no official communication concerning the changes which are to be effected, but we believe that our anticipations will be found to be in the main correction

div.head: RUSSIAN SICK AND WOUNDED.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon the American steamer "Garonne" arrived at Sues from Shanghai with Rassian sick and wounded, on their way home on "parole." The vessel entered the Cana! towards evening bound to Odessa.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: "The plague balletin for last week, which is presented to be by the Sanitary Department, is somewhat alarming. As many as 26 cases have been notified during the week, whilst 18 deaths have been recorded and only one cure effected, Damely, that of a European at MitGhamr. Of the 26 new cases, 9 have occurred at Alexandria, 10 at Damanbour, 4 at Garois (Menoufieb) I at Port Said, I at Zilta, and 1 at Barchoum-el-Sogra, Toukh district.
Since January 1, 1905, 103 cases have been notified, as compared with 647 daring the correspondig period last year.

Yesterday's bulletin records a fatal case at Alexandria, the victim being & native boy found dead at his home in Bab Sidra Barrani. This boy was a brother to the one who died on the previous day. A fatal case is reported from Port Said, 3 cases from Damanbour, one case from Ashmoun, and a recovery from Zitts.

div.head: QUARANTINE AGAINST ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Alexandria are subjected to 48 hours' quarantine and disinfection, while the rats on board must be destroyed.
A telegram from Rome announces that arrivals in Italy from Alexandria are submitted to the measures and dispositions prescribed by sanitary maritime ordinance No. 5 of 1902, against plague.
According to this ordinance, all passengers, on arriving in an Italian port, must be medioally examined, and all personal or domestic effects which are not quite clean must be disinfected.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending the 24th inst., 13 deaths from cattle plagne were recorded in! Egypt, namely, I at Rosetta, 4 at Zagazig, 3 at Hakis, I at Balbeis, 1 at Mina el kamh, 2 At Embabeh, and I at Fayoum. The number of deaths daring the corresponding period last! year was 1,607. Since the commencement of the epidemio the total number of deaths amounts to 147,278, distributed as follows - Gouvernorate, 89%, Lower Eaypt, 54,151 Upper Egypt, 92,235

div.head: EXTRAORDINARY NEGLIGENCE
div.p: In oar isane ot the 7th inst, we referred to the discovery of a corpse dressed in European clothes in a quarry pit Doar the Salt and Soda Company's works at Mex. The corpse was declared both by the caracol apd by the bompital staff to be that of # Sudanese.

M. Georges Kanaan, a Syrian pharmacist, whose brother had been missing for some time, obtained an order for the exhumation of the body, which had been buried with the clothes, and identified it as his brother's corpse. How such an appalling mistake could have been made at the caracol, and still more at the hospital, is quite inexplicable. We hope that the anthorities will take up this matter and that inqairies will also be madeas to the cause of M. Kanaan's death. The fact that a gold watch and some keys and papers which the deceased had in his possession when lest seen by his brother, were not found on the corpse makes it highly probable that the unfortunate man was robbed and murdered before being Hang into the quarry pit.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Most liner "Beti" sailed from Malta on Saturday morning and is due here to-morrow evening with passengers, mail, and general cargo.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Equateur," from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Batorday and is due bere to morrow.

div.head:
SERIOUS STABBING AFFRAY.
SHIP'S STEWARD, ATTACKED.
div.p: A serious affray took place in Alexandria harbour on Saturday at about 1 p.m., just as the S.S. "Avon" (Captain Lancaster) was about to weigh anchor. The passengers had all been embarked, and as it was lunch-time the steward, J. E. Garnham, went to the galley to see about the meal. He found that the cook, named Johd It Ragby, had not prepared anything, and on asking for explanations he was furiously attack ed by the latter with a large kitchen knife measuring about it feet. The man, who 1 must have been intoxicated, inflicted an ugly gash on the steward's right cheek, and the pair closed together, a terrible struggle taking place, in which the steward received stabs in the head and the right arm.

When the pair were separated by persons on board who heard the scuffie, the steward was seen to bave suffered considerably at the hands of the aggressor. He was losing blood freely. 'The captain bandaged up his wounds and finally sent him to the Deaconesses' Hospital, 1 while the infariated cook was taken to the la
British Consulate and placed in the lock-up. I | A preliminary enquiry into the circumstances of the case was held by Mr. Gould on Saturday afternoon, when the prisoner was remanded for trial.
The S.S. "Avon" left the harbour at 7.30 p.m. on Saturday.
We understand that the wounded steward is doing as well as can be expected.

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Pield Marshal Kiazim Pasha, Military Director of Works on the Imperial Hedjaz Railway, is expected to arrive here very shortly on an inspecting trip. Seven windmills on the Reinsch system are to be constructed for the Hedjaz railway. These windmills are to be used for raising water.

div.head: GROUNDING OF THE "FOYLE."
div.p: The British steamer "Poyle," laden with rice from Rangoon for Alexandria, is still aground near Hanish Island in the Red Sea, and her position is practically unchanged. Owing to the bad position in which she grounded, the salvage of the steamer and cargo is doubtfal. In the forehold there is 14 feet of water.

div.head: THE S.S. "HELENE RICKMERS."
div.p: The-German steamer "Helene Rickmers," I which was ashore at Ras Garib, is still at Saez | waiting for the lighters, which were left behind fall of cargo owing to the bad weather,
A tag was despatched from Suez a few days ago in search of the lighters, but has not yet returned.
A survey was held, and the steamer was found to have sustained no damage whatever. It appears that while the "Helene Rickmers" was aground she threw overboard over 4,000 bags of rice.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mgr. Kyrillos VIII., Greek-Catholic Patriarch, will probably leave Alexandria on the | 7th inst, for å stay of several months in Syria.
Prince Puad Pasha and De Martino Praha left by the Austrian steamer on Saturday.
! Daring his recent trip to the Upper Nile Sir William Garstin shot the largest elephant on record since the reconquest of the Sadan. Its tasks weigh 294 lbs.
1 The Right Rev. James Bellord, formerly

Viear Apostolic of Gibraltar, died at Nazareth House, Southend, on Tuesday morning, after a long illness. Born in London in 1847, he was for twenty-six years & British military chaplain, serving in the Zula War and in the Egyptian Expedition under Lord Wolseley. He was wounded at Tel-el-Kabir.
Oar Alexandrian readers will regret to hear that Mr. G. de Beaupais, director of the Banco di Roma, Alexandria, is seriously ill. M. de Beaupuis left Alexandria two months ago for Rome.
Bimbashi W. L Longfield, Sadan Railways Administration, has been promoted local Kaimakam.
Major W. F. Heaney, 2nd Royal Ioniskilling Fasiliers, and Rev. F. B. N. Norman Lee, MA., C.F., have been granted leave of abaence.
M. J. Lacrella Bey, chief engineer of the Technical Service, P.W.D., has been granted 3 months' leave, to date from Jaly 1.
WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
Table d'Hote Luncheons & Dinner
Served on the Torrado.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.80 P.M. DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - AMA MO
A.8.0. GYMKHANA.

Saturday's Gymkhana at the A S.C. grounds was a decided sgocess. The weather was favorable, a cool sea breeze reventing the san from disturbing anybody's comfort. The attendance, considering the date, was very fair, & large number of ladies being present, and the events were keenly contested. The proubnce of quite a strong Cairocontingent added greatly to the interest of the proceedings. Mr. M. de O. Findlay and Mrs. Findlay, the Hon. F. O. Lind. ley, Mr. and Mrs. Gould, Sir William Garstin and Mr. Wobb, Major Hopkinson, and many other well-known Anglo Egyptians watebed the events, which we describe in detail below:

TENT PEGGING.-There were 9 entries for the tent pegging, which was well won by Mr. Simonds, who took all hia pegs in very nice style. Second honors were divided between Messrs. Richmond and Trafford, who took two pegs each.

HACK SCURRY.--For bona fide Hacks, 14.1 and under, that have never run in a race at any race meeting in Egypt (Gymkhana szcepted) and do not belong to any racing stable. Catch weights, over 11 st. Distance 3 farlongs. -A field of 16 turned out for this event, which was easily won by Mr. Donaldson's Derry Boy, followed by Mr. Hoyami's Crieri and Mr. Trafford's Port Said. Mr. Donaldson could not draw the 11 st. catch weight by soupe Ibe. and the prize was therefore awarded to Mr. Hogami.

WHISTLING COON RACE. - This was the most amusing event of the day. The competitors, after sprigting for 60 yards, lined up in front of their partners, who were posted at the fence beside the judge'e box, and a wonderful combination of melodiee filled the air for halt a minute. The distracting effect of s donen tunes simultaneously whistled and the bad condition of some of the sprinters, whose exertions on foot reduced their whistling powers to a minimum, made identification difficult We are assured that a lady to whom "The British Grenadiers" was whistled, wrote down I the name of the air as "Bill Bailey," and that

There is a tavern in the town" was confused with l'he Honeysucklei and the Bee." Mris. Moore was the winner, Capt. Basset's "Home, Sweet Home" being quickly recognised, and Mrs. Gedge was second, Mr. Hemp'8"Auld Lang Byne" being equally anmistakable. Our con gratulations to the Berksbires on their musical efficiency

CIGAR AND UMBRELLA RACE.-Thirteen entries made a big field in this roe. One or two parasole suffered and one of the competitors planted his saddle dangerously near his pony's tail. Mr. Bartlett was first off but dropped the parasol he wielded, and Mr. Richmond came in winner.

LADIES' BICYCLE RACE.(lastin wins). Won by Miss E. Allen. Mrs. Kalham was & good second. | POTATO AND BUCKET OOMPETI|TION.---There were 20 entries for this event, but most of the performers seemed rather at ses. Mr. Jenkinson and Mr. Donaldson were finally given an extra run, which was won by the former, who made the best individual run in the event, getting in two potatoes out of three.
EGG AND SPOON RACE ON PONIES.This event brought 18 entries, inclading one lady, into the field, and was won by Mr. Hemp. Very few competitors arrived with their eggs unbroken.

At the close of the meeting, which did not last too long, Mrs. M. de C. Findlay kindly distribated the prizes, and receiy. ed the cheers of all present. The meeting was thoroughly well organised by the A. 8. C. stewards and was greatly enjoyed by all present. The band of the lad Royal Berkshire Regiment played selections of music during the afternoon.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB
div.p: The attention of owners is drawn to the fact that by the new iaste of the Tarf Gaide that comes into force on October 1, the maiden is increased to P.T. 5,000.

div.head: REGLEMENT SUR LA RACE
div.p: Lo "Journal Offioiol" viont do publior la ri> glouicnt sur la rago. En void la taxte: Des mesures a prendre dans les cas de rage Article Premier Lorsqu'un chien est attaint do rage ou sul- poot, declaration en Bara faito A l'autoritA ad- ministrativa dans la plus braf dAlai possible. L'obligation de fairo la declaration incoiu- bora an propriAtairo du obien, à touta peraonno chargAo da soin ou do la gardo rlu chien, ainsi qu'A tout vAtArinaire appelA à lo soignor. Si Li declaration n'a pas AtA faito, las personnes d- doasus so runt routes passiblos das poinos prA vnes par la prAsente loi, a moins qu'elles no fassent valoir un empAcheinont legitime. La declaration sera faito : Dans las gouver- norats, an gouvernorat ou kism, à Ismaiiia, au sous-gouvernorat ; dans las chafs-lieux das moudiriehs at des^marksz, au markaz; dans les villages, A l'omdoh ou au posto do police lo plus proche. Art. 2. Les personnes tenues do fairo la declaration on vortu de 1'art lor, soront egalemont tenues, sans attendro l'intorvention de l'autorite ad- ministrative, soit d'abattre lo chien, soit do l'enformer et dele tenircompletcmantisoie des personnes et des animaux. Art. 3. Lorsqu'un cas da rage ou un cas suspect ost sign ale à l'autorite administrative, tout agent autorise A cet effat par lo Ministro de 1'IntA- riaur, pourra procedor a uno ouquAte, afin do constator si d'autres chiens ont AtA, soit mordus jiar le chien enrage ou suspect, eoit en contact avec lui. Cea agents auront à cot effet tons let pouvoirs pour convoquer et entendre des 1A- moins, qoi appartiennent à unoflioier de police judiciaire, agissant en matiAre de Ilagraut delit Art. 4. Tout chien suspect pourra fltro abattu par les eoins do l'autorite administrative sans quo l'abatage puisse donnner droit à aucuno indem- nite ; toutefois, si le propriAtairo accepte do payer les frais de son entretieo au taux do P.E. 2 par joar, il pourra Atre mis en fourriAro et tenu en observation jusqu'A l'etablissement du diagnostic. En cas de rage conatatAe, l'abatage do chien onragd ainsi quo de tout chien qu'il aura mordu, sera obligatoire. Art. 5. Tout chien qui a AtA en contact avec un un chien atteint de rage ou suspect, ou qui a dte mordu par un chien suspect, pourra At re abattu, sans que l'abatage puisse donner lieu a aucuno indemnity à moins que le propriAtairo n accepte de payer les frais do son entretien an taux P.E. 2 par jour, auquel cas l'adminis- tration aura la facultd do mettro le chien en fourriAro et do la tenir en observation juaqu'A dtablissement du diagnostic. 11 en sera de mdmo pour les chions qui ont mordo des personnes lorsqu'il y a des raisons de craindre 1'existence de la rage. Art. 6. Ancon cadarre de chien atteint de rage ou suspect, ne sera enfoui sans information prda- lablo de fautoritd administrative, qui pourra fairs prooAder à l'autopsie. Art. 7. Tout propridtaire d'un chien, touts personne en ayant le soin ou la charge, devra ftciliter, en tant que de besoin, l'exdoution par l'auto- ritd administrative des dispositions qui prd- cAdent. . Art. 8. Les dispositions qoi prAoAdent seront appli- cables à tout autre animal atteint do rage ou suspect: Des precautions contre la race Art. 9. Dans toots localitd oh un cas de rage ou des cas suspects auraient dtd constatds, le moudir ou le gouyerneur pourra par un ArrAtA qui entrera en vigueor 3 jours aprAs sa publication, ordonner que les chiens circulaot dans les rues ou endroita publics, soient muselds ou ten us en laisse. 11 pourra en outre, s'il y a lieu, ordon- ner que les chiens, mfiwo tenus en laisse, soient muBelds. Dans l'un on l'autre cas, il ordonnera en mdme temps qu'ils soient munis de colliers portant sur one plaque en metal, le nom du pro- pridtaire, avec indication de es demeure. Art. 10. Lee mnselidres doivent Atre fait or de maniAre à empAoher les chiens de mordre, tout en Ieur pennottant de boire. Art. 11. Dans tonte localitd on un ArrAtA pris en vertu de l'aiticle 9 serait en vigueur, lee chiens circulant dans les rues ou endroits publics, en contravention de eet Arrdtd, pourront Atre aaisis par la police et condoita en fourriAre. Si le chien saisi est muni d'nn collier indi- quant le nom et la demeure da propridtaire, la 1'olice en evisera le propridtaire qui pourra rd- clamer le chien pendant un ddiai de 7 jours ' contre paiement des frais de son entretien au taux de P.E. 2 par jour. Co psioment n'ioter- rotnpra paa les poursuites pdnales. Si le chien u'est pas muni d'un oollier por tant les indications ci-dessus ou si le proprid- taire ne le rdclame pas 'Ians le ddiai ci deltas, le chien restera à la di-position de la police. Art. 12. L'aotoritd administrative pourra faire pro odder à tout moment à l'empoisonnement on à la destruction de tooteantre man id re. dos chiens trouvds errant dans lee rues et endroite publics. Dob peoalites Art. 13. Tonte infraction aox dispositions de la prd sente loi on des arrdtd* pris en exdention de laprdsente loi, sen pnnie d'une amende n'ex eddant pas L B. une.

TARDON ON GOLF. if anyone has the right to lay down the law j on goll, nays the "Evening Standanl," it ia the m m who has won tho open championship four times—a record only equalled by the two Morrises, "Old Tom" and "Young Tom." And in this book Harry Vardon shows that he is as jjoi 1 at preaching as at practioo. As an instruc- for be is detailed but lucid. Thoroughly as he goes into the question o( grip, stance, swing, . md the correct use of each club, his explana- tions never become involved,and are materially helped out by a numbor of excellent reproduc- tions of the author porforming the strokes cot only in the right but also, by way of awful illustration, in the wrong way. These latter poses, wo hasten to add, Vardon found it "most inconveuient andjdifficalt" to assume. But they wear a fairly familiar look, somehow. Vardon addresses himself to an audience alike of beginners and of proficients. He keeps the "fancy" strokos in a separate cate- gory, howevor. To the boginner he is at the same time encouraging and depressing.' It is never too late to start. Even at forty or forty-five wo can reach scratch or very near it, but—at least three months' persis- tent and laborious practice is a tine qua non. As a shining example ho points to Mr. Balfour as having, it is stated, "spent a miserable fortnight in bunkers only, learning how to get out of them from every possiblo position." It is interesting Jo hear that in Vardon's opinion the Premier isnowa very good and steady player, and might be still better but for Parliamentary cares. Which is the master stroke in golf 1 That is another very interesting point on which he records his opinion. He awards tho palm to none of the ordinary shots, however perfect 1'he greatest is tho stroke to which a big pull or slice is intentionally applied for the accom- plishment of a specific purpose, which could nut be achieved in any other way.

"I call it the master shot because, to ac- complish it with any certainty and perfection, it is oo difficult even to the experienced golfer, because it calls for tho most absolute command over the club and every nerve and sinew of the body, and the courageous heart of the true sportsman whom no difficulty may daunt, and because, when properly done, it ia a splendid thing to soo, and for a certainty results in material gain to tho mab who played it" The best course in the world, in Vardon's estimation, is Sandwich. He acknowledges that he is at varianoe here with many of the best authorities on the gamo, but Ire gives good reasons for his choice. Prestwick and Hoy lake be puts next, but his verdict on St Andrews, passed, of course, before the reoent championships, is one of distinctly modified praise. It is "a good oourso generally, but its bunkers are badly placed." And here the author is certainly uot alone in his opinion. lu the lighter portion of his book, which, we must add, is written in really admirable style, Vardon has collected a number of delightful golf auecdot.-, with comparatively few chest- nuts among them. His visit to America in 1900, when he won the American Champion- ship, was notable, among other thing*, for the achievements of the reporters, who, trne to their tradition of sensationalism, announced, one that he "carried away the green with his drive," another that he "dropped dead at the hole." Pacts, however, were as queer as fiction iu some parts of tho trip. On one Florida course men with sticks had to bo kept con- stantly employed on the greens to keep the locusts ofl the lines of the pntts !

But the best stories are to be found in the chapter "Conoeming Caddies." There was a busy day on/jne occasion at North Berwick, when all the regular caddies were out, and fishermen were drafted into the service. A well known player engaged one of them, though the recruit acknowledged that he only knew very little of the game.

"This player happened to be left-handed, and took up his etanoe on the first tee aooord- ingly, whereupon the son of the sea at once' adopted tho part of tutor, and with some warmth and show of ooutempt exclaimed loudly, 'I dinna ken much about the game, l-t ye dinna keen a wee bit Mon, ye're stand- ing on the wrong side of the baw! Awa' to . the other side ?' "

More disconcerting and less amusing (to the player) was the following experience "Two golfers of some Highland eelebritywere playing a match one day at Luff ness, and after a hard round they came to the eighteenth tee all square and but this one bole to play. At this critical stage of the game the caddie of one of them approached his master and nervously whispered to him, 'Please sir, wad ye do your very best here, for there's money on this match.' And the goiter did try to do his very best indeed, but he pressed and he foozled, and he lost the hole and the match. Sympathetically he turned to his caddie to ask him what wus the amount of the lost wager that he might pay it for him and soften his disappointment 'It was a penny, sir,' said Use boy."

Mr. Balfour figures in more than one plea- sant little incident "He has a remarkable memory for the caddies who have served him, and onoe, when on the tee, just about to engage in a foursome, he re- cognised one of his opponents' caddies as a boy who on a former occasion had carried his own clubs, and be nodded to him kindly. Natarally the caddie was immensely pleased, and torn ing to one of his colleagues fie remarked, 'Ye see boo we Conservatives ken aue anither " But we are inclined to think that the finest illustration of the "humanity" of the club- carfying class is to be fonnd in a story of a famous caddie nazped Sandy Smith. He "am- or,e day carrying for a player who had the good fortune to be no fewer than six holes up on his opponent by the time the eighth hole was reached. At this green something having gone wrong with tho reckoning of the strokes, there was a mild dispute as to whether the hole had been won by Sandy's man or whether it had boon halved. Bventually it was agreed that it was halved, bat as the players moved away to the next tee, he who was six down being ont of earshot in front, his opponent remarked to Sandy, 'You know, Sandy, I still think I won that holo after all.' Sandy seemed shocked at such a cold-blooded greed for holes, und re- provingly, vory seriously, and sharply said to his employer, 'Haud yor tongno, sir; haud yer tongue. Wad ye break the man's heart Vardon has much that is interesting to tell, too, in the way of reminiscence and of his observations in great matches. And whatever he has to say he says well. It is a book worthy of a place in the library of every golfer.

In "Country Life in Amerioa," Mr. H.K. Job, an Amerioan naturalist, gives an account, illustrated by photographs, of an egret rookery he discovered in a southern State, unknown to the hnnter and rigorously protected. Ho says :—

A long sail up a series of narrow, tortuous creeks, between walls of impassable mud and through immonse salt marshes, found ns anchored at the desired locality. Even before the anchor took the mud, late in the afternoon, I had seen the sun glance on the dazzling whiteness of several dozens of egrets at they flew to and from the marsh, immaculate amid the southern mud whieh sticks like glue. After one false start, we found a man who knew the location of the rookery, in e greet oypress swamp. First we tramped a mile over a wood- land trail, whan we came to an arm of muddy wator under high, over-arching trees, and a small flat-bottomed skiff. Working two pad- dles wo glided along, and soon emerged in a great area of cypress trees growing out of the water. Alligators and turtles splashed be- fore us, end buzzards end ospreys wheeled overhead. From the cypress branches, with their delioate needle-foliage of pale green, hung the streaming grey moss. Pairs of wood-duck started up now sad then from

A month ago the Ambassadors of holidays, these and other sports always are pathiser to hold him up as a man of parts and j Russia, Germany, Turkey, and Amenca were indulged in. Those at night are the most a downright good fellow. All are agreed that seen, and their promise obtained to forward a attractive, when the rocks and bay are alone be is not worth considering, and that he memorial on the subject to their respective illaminated with fireworks and fire of various1 must be frowned out of existence. Possibly, as Governments. I*st week a small deputation, Although the movement for establishing peasants' banka in India seems tOj.mako very slow progress, it has undoubtedly gained ground in some localities. The ryot is, as m rule, conservative in all his tendencies, -and it has been found very difficult to convinoe these humble tillers of the soil that the time has come to break off financial relations with the village usurer. But even their obstinate addic- tion to ancient ways cannot g6t rid of the gain ooosequent on obtaining advances from banks at 12 per cent, instead of paying ten times that rate to some grasping money- lender on the same security. On first estab- lishment, the new institutions are invariably regarded with suspicion and dislike, all manner of libellous stories being disseminated by the pests they seek to supplant In one instance, the ryots were induoed to believe gthat the very latest device of the Siroar to disoover the innovation was the hidden taxable resources of the agricultural popu- lation. But the temptation to obtain loans on such comparatively easy conditions led some of the more enlightened peasants to make trial of the new system, and when no harm resulted to these bold experimentalists, the more timorous embarked in the venture. It is calculated that by fixing the rate of interest as high as 13 per oent adequate provision is made for famine years and their inevitable losses. But that theory still requires to be put to the test; even the usurers suffer heavy losses at such times.
HORSES IN BATTLE.
